content.content:
<context>The only difference found between men and women with severe COVID-19 was that the procalcitonin (inflammation index) was higher in men than in women (Table 3).

<relevance>0.7740224003791809</relevance>
<context>Men with severe versus moderate illness had higher BMI and CRP: Women with severe versus moderate disease had higher INR levels and longer hospital stays.</context>
<relevance>0.7367681264877319</relevance>
<context>WBC, white blood cells; NEU , neutrophils; LYM, lymphocytes; NLR, neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio; PLT, platelets; CRP; C-reactive protein; PCT, procalcitonin; INR, international nor malized ratio; APTT, activated thromboplastin time; ALT, alanine transaminase; AST, aspartate transferase; LOS, length of hospital stay partial

Laboratory parameters were analyzed in COVID-19 patients in the context of age- and sex-related changes (Tables 2 and 3) Both men and women with COVID-19 were older in the severe than in the moderate group.</context>
<relevance>0.695465087890625</relevance>

content:
TextBlock(citations=None, text='<result>
Based on the information found, the key differences in COVID-19 severity between men and women were:

- Men with severe COVID-19 had higher procalcitonin (an inflammation marker) compared to women with severe COVID-19.
- Men with severe COVID-19 had higher BMI (body mass index) and CRP (C-reactive protein, another inflammation marker) compared to men with moderate COVID-19.
- Women with severe COVID-19 had higher INR (international normalized ratio, a blood clotting measure) and longer hospital stays compared to women with moderate COVID-19.

Overall, the data suggests that men tended to have more severe inflammatory responses to COVID-19, while women had more severe blood clotting issues. However, the differences were relatively small, and both genders experienced increased severity with older age.
</result>', type='text')

final_output_text:
<result>
Based on the information found, the key differences in COVID-19 severity between men and women were:

- Men with severe COVID-19 had higher procalcitonin (an inflammation marker) compared to women with severe COVID-19.
- Men with severe COVID-19 had higher BMI (body mass index) and CRP (C-reactive protein, another inflammation marker) compared to men with moderate COVID-19.
- Women with severe COVID-19 had higher INR (international normalized ratio, a blood clotting measure) and longer hospital stays compared to women with moderate COVID-19.

Overall, the data suggests that men tended to have more severe inflammatory responses to COVID-19, while women had more severe blood clotting issues. However, the differences were relatively small, and both genders experienced increased severity with older age.
</result>

final_output_text:
<result>
The key differences in COVID-19 severity between men and women were:

- Men with severe COVID-19 had higher levels of procalcitonin, an inflammation marker, compared to women with severe COVID-19.
- Men with severe COVID-19 had higher BMI (body mass index) and CRP (C-reactive protein, another inflammation marker) compared to men with moderate COVID-19.
- Women with severe COVID-19 had higher INR (international normalized ratio, a blood clotting measure) and longer hospital stays compared to women with moderate COVID-19.

Overall, the data suggests that men tended to have more severe inflammatory responses to COVID-19, while women had more severe blood clotting issues. However, the differences were relatively small, and both genders experienced increased severity with older age.
</result>
